Award.AwardTitle: Travel Support for Minority Students Attending Institute for Operations Research and the Management Sciences (INFORMS) Annual Meetings for Years 2015, 2016, and 2017

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant provides funding for underrepresented minority graduate students to attend the Institute for Operations Research and the Management Sciences (INFORMS) annual meetings for years 2015, 2016, and 2017. The students supported by this grant will either be engaged in the doctoral colloquium of the education forum of INFORMS or presenting a technical talk at the conference. Hence, the students will acquire necessary professional development skills to become an integral part of the operations research and management science profession. In addition, the experience gained through the professional development, the presentation of research, and the interaction with senior professionals in the field will positively affect the students' persistence to obtain a doctoral degree and practice in the field.

If successful, the efforts supported by this grant will increase the number and diversity of operations research professionals. Also, the interaction of the students with known professionals in the field along with other students will assist in developing a network of colleagues to provide guidance to further their careers. The primary goal of this work is to increase the exposure of underrepresented minority graduate students to researchers in operations research and vice versa, broadening the perception of both. The secondary goal is to foster these individuals into positions within the professoriate.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant provided funding for a total of 17 underrepresented minority graduate students to attend the Institute for Operations Research and the Management Sciences (INFORMS) annual meetings for years 2015-2018. The students supported by this grant were actively engaged in various activities of the conference such as the doctoral colloquium of the education forum of INFORMS or by presenting a technical talk at the conference. Hence, the students acquired necessary professional development skills to become an integral part of the operations research and management science profession. In addition, the experience gained through the professional development, the presentation of research, and the interaction with senior professionals in the field positively affected the students' persistence to obtain a doctoral degree and practice in the field.  This was verified through documented testimonies of the students. 

In all, the efforts supported by this grant increased the number and diversity of operations research professionals. Of the eight students who have achieved their doctoral degree over the years of the grant, three have obtained academic positions such as Southern Methodist University, the Ohio State University, and Carnegie Mellon.  The other graduates have obtained positions in such companies as Wayfair, John Hopkins Applied Physics Lab, Intel, Air Force Research Lab, and Cisco Systems.  Furthermore, the interaction of the students with known professionals in the field along with other students will assist in developing a network of colleagues to provide guidance to further their careers. The primary goal of this work was to increase the exposure of underrepresented minority graduate students to researchers in operations research and vice versa, broadening the perception of both. The secondary goal was to foster these individuals into positions within the professoriate.  Both goals were achieved.
